education.val: [09.2012 ‚Äî 06.2016] Donbas State Technical University (computer engineer, bachelor degree)

list.name: Lead skills
list.descr:
In the tech lead position I did:
  • mentoring engineers
  • one-to-one sessions
  • code review
  • architecture design sessions
  • troubleshooting and helping
  • interviews (recruitment)
  • implemented a bonus system

list.name: ESnext / JS
list.descr:
I know the difference between `call` and `apply`,
I know why `typeof [] === "object"` and why you have to be careful with method `.sort()`.
I can implement a polyfill for `fetch` or add a new method `.any()` for all promises in your code.
I know how works event loop in JS.
Really like FRP.

list.name: Typescript
list.descr:
I've become a fan of strictly typed code with Angular.
Generics is my love.
I often use some advanced TS tricks like type guards, conditional types, inferring in my projects, but given the fact that TS is a "Turing-complete" language, you can do a lot of other interesting things.

list.name: RxJS
list.descr:
When you come to RxJS - your mind is blown.
But after that, you can't imagine a better tool to organize async staff.
I know the difference between `switchMap` and `mergeMap` when to use cold observables instead of hot (or vice versa), and how `shareReplay()` will help you with this.

list.name: Angular 13+
list.descr:
A lot of time I've been involved in performance issues in angular, so I know how to tame `zone.js` or turn it off at all (but it's more complicated).
Very much looking forward to v14 with strictly typed forms and optional modules (SCAM-like).
Angular stands out with its DI/IoC, it's a very powerful tool.

list.name: HTML5 + CSS3 + SVG
list.descr: div[style*="height: 70px"] { height: 40px !important; }

list.name: Git
list.descr:
Often use interactive rebase.
Once in my life, I used `bisect' and it helped.

list.name: Linux
list.descr: I know how to use grep, I can write a simple bash script, I can monitor an instance via top/htop

list.name: Node.js
list.descr:
I have experience with koa+mongoose in my own pet project.
I also often inspect some bundler's stuff in node_modules for demystifying how it works.
Very often used node for different utility purposes, like iterating, creating and modifying files, some kind of generators, some global refactoring (ts-morph), staff improved DX, etc.
Node often is very useful

list.name: GraphQL/Apollo
list.descr: Used graphql federation with apollo-client on a front-end as a primary BFF in robota.ua

list.name: SASS/postcss/tailwindcss
list.descr: tailwind is my favorite one.

list.name: Docker
list.descr: Often use for work and/or personal purposes.

list.name: k8s

list.name: CI/CD

Had experience with transferring CI of our frontend from TeamCity to
Github Actions and set up then (very interesting activity to the honest).

list.name: MySQL

I had experience with MySQL during my students' years.
I've developed a structure of DB as a part of my diploma work

list.name: Python, C#, Java
list.descr: Wrote something

list.name: ducky app
list.descr: A promising startup that unfortunately stopped funding because of the war

list.name: robota.ua: front-end tech lead
list.descr:
In this role I focused on complex problems, for example:

‚Äì slow builds: I implemented a non-trivial cache system for CI/CD on github actions, updated our stack to modern and fast webpack5, implemented some tricks for speed-up in dependencies via patch-package
‚Äì improved performance (core web-vitals: LCP, TTFB, FID)
‚Äì improved developer experience for engineers, for example: some routine things, like generate code from schema, become easier
‚Äì implemented typesript's strict mode, spellcheckers and a lot of linters to avoid mistakes of human nature.

Besides technical things I did a mentoring, recruitment and various events to create a good atmosphere in the direction of the front-end (for example I implemented a bonus system based on code review and assistance to other)

list.name: robota.ua: front-end engineer in a jobseeker team
list.descr: Worked in a jobseeker team. During this time I managed to develop using different frameworks and approaches: knockout, react+redux, angular. Last 3 years robota.ua finally settled on the choice: angular + graphql and we increased our expertise in this direction

list.name: ITVDN [part-time]
list.descr:
In parallel with the main job (I mean part-time), I was involved with the development of the React+Redux course on ITVDN platform. As for me, it was very interesting & challenging experience, but to repeat something like this I am not going to in the nearest future :)
You can watch by the following link - ITVDN and YouTube (promo cropped video)

list.name: pickoose.com
list.descr: The startup, I had come there to re-develop the existing front-end from angular v1 to React + Redux + Restful eco-system. I got an interesting experience with developing an internal messenger. Unfortunately, the startup did not receive investments and I had to look for a job again.

list.name: Lazard Export
list.descr:
There is my first encounter with the stack React + Redux + Webpack (it was a time when you had to set it up yourself).
I've been doing a dashboard for an IoT project. It was something like a smart lock, where you can unlock the door by credit card and manage access in the dashboard.

list.name: ITCG
list.descr: Development of promo and landing pages. Mostly they were vanilla JS & a lot of jQuery-like. I had experience in the role of full-stack for one of the project - Guerlain, I've implemented the whole project from ground zero (back-end and front-end) using python (Django).

list.name: Freelance
list.descr:
We had two bags of wordpress, seventy-five pellets of free html5 templates...
Not that we needed all that for the freelance, but once you get locked into a serious web-sites collection, the tendency is to push it as far as you can ¬©
